data.title: Westworld (2016– )
data.summary: Set at the intersection of the near future and the reimagined past, explore a world in which every human appetite can be indulged without consequence.

data.title: Deadwood (2004–2006)
data.summary: A show set in the late 1800s, revolving around the characters of Deadwood, South Dakota; a town of deep corruption and crime.

data.title: Lonesome Dove (1989)
data.summary: Two former Texas Rangers renew their spirit of adventure as they and several other residents of a small Texas town join a cattle drive to the Montana Territory.

data.title: Disneyland (1954–1991)
data.summary: A Disney-produced anthology covering many different genres.

data.title: Have Gun - Will Travel (1957–1963)
data.summary: The adventures of a gentlemanly gunfighter for hire.

data.title: Centennial (1978–1979)
data.summary: The economic and cultural growth of Colorado spanning two centuries from the mid 1700s to the late 1970s.

data.title: Yellowstone (2018– )
data.summary: A ranching family in Montana faces off against others encroaching on their land.

data.title: Godless (2017)
data.summary: In the 1880s American West murderous outlaw gang leader Frank Griffin hunts for ex-protege Roy Goode. Frank's chase leads him to La Belle, New Mexico - a town inhabited, after a mining disaster, almost entirely by women.

data.title: The Adventures of Brisco County Jr. (1993–1994)
data.summary: A bounty hunter rides the Old West, fighting bad guys, many with futuristic-type gadgets.

data.title: Paradise (1988–1990)
data.summary: Gunfighter Ethan Cord, left to raise his dead sister's children, tries to settle down in the town of Paradise, but finds that his past continues to haunt him.

data.title: Longmire (2012–2017)
data.summary: Walt Longmire is the dedicated and unflappable sheriff of Absaroka County, Wyoming. Widowed only a year, he is a man in psychic repair but buries his pain behind his brave face, unassuming grin and dry wit.

data.title: Hell on Wheels (2011–2016)
data.summary: Cullen Bohannon, a former soldier and slaveholder, follows the track of a band of Union soldiers, the killers of his wife. This brings him to the middle of one of the biggest projects in US...                See full summary »

data.title: The Rifleman (1958–1963)
data.summary: The adventures of a Wild West rancher wielding a customized rapid fire Winchester rifle and his son.

data.title: How the West Was Won (1976– )
data.summary: The Macahans, a family from Virginia, headed by Zeb Macahan, travel across the country to pioneer a new land and a new home in the American West.

data.title: Zorro (1957–1959)
data.summary: Don Diego de la Vega opposes the corrupt tyrants of Spanish California as the masked swordsman, Zorro.

data.title: Trackdown (1957–1959)
data.summary: Texas Ranger Hoby Gilman travels the Old West tracking down assorted killers, bank robbers, horse thieves and other evildoers.

data.title: The Wild Wild West (1965–1969)
data.summary: Two Secret Service Agents, equipped with a wide array of gizmos, work for the government in the Old West.

data.title: Rawhide (1959–1965)
data.summary: Gil Favor is trail boss of a continuous cattle drive. He is assisted by Rowdy Yates. The crew runs into characters and adventures along the way.

data.title: Maverick (1957–1962)
data.summary: Bret and Bart Maverick (and in later seasons, their English cousin, Beau) are well dressed gamblers who migrate from town to town always looking for a good game. Poker (five-card draw) is ...                See full summary »

data.title: Cheyenne (1955–1963)
data.summary: After the Civil War, nomadic adventurer Cheyenne Bodie roamed the west looking for fights, women, and bad guys to beat up. His job changed from episode to episode.

data.title: Wanted: Dead or Alive (1958–1961)
data.summary: A Civil War veteran with a sawed-off rifle as a holstered weapon makes a living as a bounty hunter in the Wild West of the 1870s.

data.title: Into the West (2005– )
data.summary: Tales from the American West in the 19th century, told from the perspective of two families, one of white settlers and one of Native Americans.

data.title: Lawman (1958–1962)
data.summary: This is the story of Marshal Dan Troop of Laramie, Wyoming, and his Deputy Johnny McKay, an orphan Troop took under his wing. In the second season, Lily Merrill opens The Birdcage Saloon, ...                See full summary »

data.title: Yancy Derringer (1958–1959)
data.summary: Yancy Derringer, an ex-Confederate soldier turned gambler, was a suave lady's man in New Orleans, Louisiana. In reality, he was working for John Colton, the civil administrator of the city....                See full summary »

data.title: Hawkeye and the Last of the Mohicans (1957)
data.summary: Nat Cutler, known as Hawkeye, is a fur trader. With his faithful Indian companion Chingachgook, the last of the Mohican tribe, he fights to protect settlers against the raiding Huron ...                See full summary »

data.title: Gunsmoke (1955–1975)
data.summary: Marshal Matt Dillon keeps the peace in rough and tumble Dodge City.

data.title: Hatfields & McCoys (2012)
data.summary: Dramatization of the bitter blood feud between the two families on the West Virginia/Kentucky border in the years after the Civil War.

data.title: Sky King (1951–1962)
data.summary: "From out of the clear blue of the western sky comes Sky King" was the familiar opening to television's premier aviation program. Operating from his Flying Crown Ranch in Arizona, Sky King,...                See full summary »

data.title: The Lone Ranger (1949–1957)
data.summary: The adventures of the masked hero and his Native American partner.

data.title: Tales of Wells Fargo (1957–1962)
data.summary: Agent Jim Hardie shifts over its history from being mostly an Agent helping Wells Fargo cope with bad guys, to being the owner of a ranch near San Francisco, California, who still does some...                See full summary »

data.title: The Rebel (1959–1961)
data.summary: After the end of the Civil War, a former Confederate Army private roams the Wild West, and, as a rogue drifter, gets involved in helping out various settlers threatened by various bad guys.

data.title: Hopalong Cassidy (1952–1954)
data.summary: Hopalong and his horse Topper catch bad guys with Red Connors for comic relief.

data.title: Kung Fu (1972–1975)
data.summary: The adventures of a Shaolin Monk as he wanders the American West armed only with his skill in Kung Fu.

data.title: The High Chaparral (1967–1971)
data.summary: The Cannon family runs the High Chaparral Ranch in the Arizona Territory in 1870s. Big John wants to establish his cattle empire despite Indian hostility. He's aided by brother Buck and son...                See full summary »

data.title: Laramie (1959–1963)
data.summary: It is the 1870s in the Wyoming Territory. Slim Sherman and his fourteen-year-old brother Andy try to hang on to their ranch after their father was shot by a land grabber. They augment their...                See full summary »

data.title: Riverboat (1959–1961)
data.summary: Grey Holden wins a river boat in a poker game, which he then pilots, along with his crew, in various adventures along the Mississippi River. This action series is set in the nineteenth century.

data.title: Broken Trail (2006– )
data.summary: A veteran cowboy and his nephew save five Chinese girls from prostitution while trekking from Oregon to Wyoming.

data.title: The Young Riders (1989–1992)
data.summary: The adventures of the riders of the Pony Express.

data.title: The Sacketts (1979)
data.summary: After the Civil War, Tennessee brothers Orrin and Tyrel Sackett are herding cattle out West while Tell Sackett is prospecting for gold in the hills.

data.title: Zane Grey Theater (1956–1961)
data.summary: An anthology based (earlier more so than later) on the novels and stories of Zane Grey. Dick Powell was often the star, as well as the host.

data.title: Sergeant Preston of the Yukon (1955–1958)
data.summary: Canadian Mountie Sgt. Preston patrols the wilds of the Yukon with his horse Rex and his faithful dog Yukon King, battling both the elements and criminals.

data.title: The Virginian (1962–1971)
data.summary: The Shiloh Ranch in Wyoming Territory of the 1890s is owned in sequence by Judge Garth, the Grainger brothers, and Colonel MacKenzie. It is the setting for a variety of stories, many more ...                See full summary »

data.title: The Big Valley (1965–1969)
data.summary: The Wild West adventures of the Barkley family in California's San Joaquin Valley.

data.title: Death Valley Days (1952–1970)
data.summary: Western stories and legends based, and filmed, in and around Death Valley, California. One of the longest-running Western series, originating on radio in the 1930s. The continuing sponsor was "20 Mule Team" Borax, a product formerly mined in Death Valley.

data.title: Alias Smith and Jones (1971–1973)
data.summary: Hannibal Heyes and Kid Curry, two of the most wanted outlaws in the history of the West, are popular "with everyone except the railroads and the banks", since "in all the trains and banks ...                See full summary »

data.title: The Magnificent Seven (1998–2000)
data.summary: When an Indian village is threatened by ex-Confederate soldiers, several villagers head out to seek help. They recruit seven men, each with unique skills, who return to the village and take...                See full summary »

data.title: The Life and Legend of Wyatt Earp (1955–1961)
data.summary: Marshal Earp keeps the law, first in Kansas and later in Arizona, using his over-sized pistols and a variety of sidekicks. Most of the saga is based loosely on fact, with historical badguys...                See full summary »

data.title: The Life and Times of Grizzly Adams (1977–1978)
data.summary: An innocent fugitive from the law lives in the wilderness with a grizzly bear companion and helps passers-by in the forest.

data.title: Quick Draw (2013–2014)
data.summary: Sheriff John Henry Hoyle and his reluctant Deputy Eli introduce the emerging science of forensics to an 1875 Kansas town.

data.title: Legend (1995– )
data.summary: Ernest Pratt, a dime-store novelist in the old west, lives with his scientist friend Professor Janos Bartok in the small town of Sheridan, Colorado. The people of Sheridan mistakenly ...                See full summary »

data.title: The Son (2017– )
data.summary: A multi-generational epic telling of the story of America's birth as a superpower through the bloody rise and fall of one Texas oil empire.

data.title: Damnation (2017–2018)
data.summary: An epic saga about the secret history of the 1930s American heartland, centering on the mythic conflict and bloody struggle between big money and the downtrodden.

data.title: Branded (1965–1966)
data.summary: In the 1880s Jason McCord travels the country trying to prove he's no coward. He needs to do this because the military career of this West point graduate came to an end when he was thrown out of the army after being accused of cowardice.

data.title: Here Come the Brides (1968–1970)
data.summary: The adventures of a logging work team and the marriageable single women sent to them in post-American Civil War Seattle in the Washington Territory.

data.title: Lonesome Dove: The Outlaw Years (1995–1996)
data.summary: "Lonesome Dove: The Outlaw Years" begins two years after the end of "Lonesome Dove". After two years spent bounty hunting, womanizing, and drinking away the painful memories of his late ...                See full summary »

data.title: Sugarfoot (1957–1961)
data.summary: Correspondence-school law graduate Tom Brewster travels west to seek his fortune. Unfortunately, his "cowboy" abilities leave a lot to be desired and earn him the nickname "Sugarfoot", ...                See full summary »

data.title: Circus Boy (1956–1958)
data.summary: 12-year-old Corky has been adopted by a traveling circus owned by Big Tim Champion. He is water boy to baby elephant Bimbo and otherwise participates in the behind-the-scenes life of the circus.

data.title: Wynonna Earp (2016– )
data.summary: Based on the IDW Comic, Wynonna Earp follows Wyatt Earp's great great-granddaughter as she battles demons and other creatures. With her unique abilities and a posse of dysfunctional allies,...                See full summary »

data.title: Wagon Train (1957–1965)
data.summary: Stories of the journeys of a wagon train as it leaves post-Civil War Missouri on its way to California through the plains, deserts, and Rocky Mountains. The first treks were led by gruff, ...                See full summary »

data.title: Klondike (2014– )
data.summary: The lives of two childhood best friends, Bill and Epstein, in the late 1890s as they flock to the gold rush capital in the untamed Yukon Territory. This man-versus-nature tale places our ...                See full summary »

data.title: Daniel Boone (1964–1970)
data.summary: Frontier hero Daniel Boone conducts surveys and expeditions around Boonesborough, running into both friendly and hostile Indians, just before and during the Revolutionary War.

data.title: Rough Riders (1997– )
data.summary: Undersecretary of the Navy Theodore Roosevelt resigns to form a volunteer militia unit called "The Rough Riders" to fight in the Spanish-American War.

data.title: Shane (1966– )
data.summary: Shane works for the Starett family, a young widow, her son, and her aging father-in-law, protecting them against the anti-sodbuster rancher Ryker and other perils plaguing the Old West.

data.title: Cimarron Strip (1967–1968)
data.summary: The western adventures of tough, but fair, Marshal Jim Crown.

data.title: Little House on the Prairie (1974–1983)
data.summary: The life and adventures of the Ingalls family in the nineteenth century American Midwest.

data.title: Bonanza (1959–1973)
data.summary: The adventures of Ben Cartwright and his sons as they run and defend their ranch while helping the surrounding community.

data.title: F Troop (1965–1967)
data.summary: The misadventures of the staff and neighbors of a remote U.S. Army outpost in the Wild West.

data.title: Streets of Laredo (1995)
data.summary: Captain Woodrow Call, now retired from the Rangers, is a bounty hunter. He is hired by an eastern rail baron to track down Joey Garza, a new kind of killer, only a boy, who kills from a ...                See full summary »

data.title: Johnny Ringo (1959–1960)
data.summary: Ex-gunfighter Johnny Ringo is now the sheriff of a small Western town, and attempts to keep the peace with the aid of his deputy, Cully, and his girl, Laura Thomas.

data.title: Annie Oakley (1954–1957)
data.summary: A fictionalized account of the life of legendary Wild West sharpshooter Annie Oakley. Set in the quiet western town of Diablo, Annie and her little brother Tagg made sure that outlaws who ...                See full summary »

data.title: Lonesome Dove: The Series (1994–1995)
data.summary: The series revolved around the life and times of Newt Call as he set out to make his way in the world. Newt participated in some of the major events of the Western era while encountering ...                See full summary »

data.title: Bat Masterson (1958–1961)
data.summary: Dressed-up dandy (derby and cane), gambler and lawman roams the West charming women and defending the unjustly accused. His primary weapon was his wit (and cane) rather than his gun.

data.title: The Cisco Kid (1950–1956)
data.summary: The Cisco Kid and his English-mangling sidekick Pancho travel the old west in the grand tradition of the Lone Ranger, righting wrongs and fighting injustice wherever they find it.

data.title: The Quest (1976)
data.summary: Morgan and Quentin Beaudine are two brothers in the West, who were separated as children, when Morgan and their sister were stolen by some Indians. Morgan would spend several years with ...                See full summary »

data.title: Barbary Coast (1975–1976)
data.summary: The wild wild west adventures of 19th-century agents Jeff Cable and Cash Conover.

data.title: The American West (2016– )
data.summary: This series will provide unprecedented access to the wilderness, frontier lawlessness, and bloodshed of the 40 years between the end of the American Civil War and after the turn of the 20th...                See full summary »

data.title: Snowy River: The McGregor Saga (1993–1996)
data.summary: Based on Banjo Paterson's poem "Man From Snowy River", this series takes place in Paterson's Ridge, a small town set in the mountains near Melbourne, during the late 19th century. It tells ...                See full summary »

data.title: Return to Lonesome Dove (1993)
data.summary: Captain Call has just buried Gus at Lonesome Dove and plans to head back to his ranch in Montana. Looking at a herd of wild Mustangs, he decides to drive them north with the help of Isom ...                See full summary »

data.title: An Klondike (2015– )
data.summary: The story of the Connolly Brothers; three Irish emigrants who travel from Montana to the Yukon during the Klondike gold rush of the 1890's in the hope of striking it rich.

data.title: The Roy Rogers Show (1951–1957)
data.summary: The Double R Ranch featured "The King of the Cowboys" Roy, his "Smartest Horse in the Movies" Trigger, "Queen of the West" Dale, her horse Buttermilk, their dog Bullet, and even Pat's jeep, Nellybelle.

data.title: The Adventures of Rin Tin Tin (1954–1959)
data.summary: Rusty was orphaned in an Indian raid. He and his dog Rin Tin Tin were adopted by the troops at Fort Apache in Arizona, and helped establish law and order in and around Mesa Grande.

data.title: Lancer (1968–1970)
data.summary: "Bonanza" clone about the Lancer family and its ranch.

data.title: Tin Man (2007)
data.summary: A re-imagining of L. Frank Baum's classic "The Wizard of Oz".

data.title: Comanche Moon (2008)
data.summary: The adventures and love lives of young Texas Rangers Woodrow Call and Augustus McRae leading up to their retirement to the city of Lonesome Dove.

data.title: Dead Man's Walk (1996)
data.summary: In this prequel to "Lonesome Dove", two young men join the Texas Rangers unit that's on a mission to annex Santa Fe.

data.title: Zorro (1990–1993)
data.summary: In nineteenth century Spanish California, heroic masked swordsman Zorro, who's actually a local nobleman, must protect his friends and small town (or pueblo) of Los Angeles from its corrupt magistrate (or alcalde) and other menaces.

data.title: Queen of Swords (2000–2001)
data.summary: A young woman, returns to her home in California after her father's mysterious death. There, she becomes a symbol, the queen of swords, fighting for justice and trying to right the wrongs the colonel has done.

data.title: Texas Rising (2015)
data.summary: The story of how the Texas Rangers were created.

data.title: The Pinkertons (2014– )
data.summary: A father and son team up with America's first female detective to solve crimes in the Wild West.

data.title: Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman (1993–1998)
data.summary: The trials and adventures of a female doctor in a small wild west town.

data.title: Strange Empire (2014–2015)
data.summary: In 1869 Janestown on the Alberta-Montana border, three women band together for survival after the men in their town are murdered.

data.title: Killer Women (2014)
data.summary: Centers on Molly Parker, one of only two women in the notoriously male Texas Rangers, a ballsy, beautiful badass who knows how to get to the truth and isn't afraid to ruffle a few feathers on her way there.

data.title: Walker, Texas Ranger (1993–2001)
data.summary: Walker, a martial artist, and his partner Trivette are Texas Rangers. They make it their business to battle crime in Dallas and all around the State of Texas.

data.title: The Barbary Coast
data.summary: Thousands of prospectors, adventurers and migrants travel to California in 1849 searching for gold in the Barbary Coast region.

data.title: Outrider (2018– )
data.summary: A deputy teams with a ruthless Marshall to track a legendary outlaw.
